notes: GMC Model 16 three-quarter-ton light commercial truck (1916-1919). Featured inline-4 gasoline engine, brass-era construction with wooden-spoke wheels. Hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes on rear wheels only, magneto ignition. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects brass-era fragile construction, hand-fitted components, obsolete ignition/brake systems, wooden components requiring specialized restoration, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC K-16 one-ton military troop carrier for WWI U.S. Army use (1917-1919). Heavy-duty inline-4 engine, reinforced frame for military service. Featured open-cab design with troop seating area. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects WWI-era brass construction, military-spec variations, hand-fitted components, magneto ignition, mechanical brakes, wooden components, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck / WWI military vehicle articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC ambulance chassis for U.S. Army Medical Corps in WWI (1917-1918). Heavy-duty truck chassis with ambulance body by various coachbuilders. Featured inline-4 engine and reinforced suspension for medical transport. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects WWI brass-era construction, military ambulance specifications, hand-fitted components, magneto ignition, mechanical brakes only, wooden body components, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck / WWI medical vehicle articles, December 19, 2024 revision.
